basics.name: Feresa Cabrera
basics.label: Ph.D., Plant Molecular Biology
basics.summary: I'm a computational evolutionary biologist with more than 7 years of experience in molecular biological research. As I approach the completion of my PhD in Plant Molecular Biology in 2024, I am initiating my search for a Scientist position in the Biotech and Tech space.

skills.name: Molecular Biology
keywords: DNA and RNA isolation and purification

courses: Dissertation: Illuminating the Diversity of Deep Reef Flora: Genomic Insights Uncover Novel Biodiversity and Genomic Novelties in the Evolution of Rhodophyta Associated with the Hawaiian Mesophotic Ecosystems

work.company: University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa School of Life Sciences
highlights: Lead and co-authored 12 publications describing over 20 species and 1 genus new to science as part of the NSF Biodiversity Survey of Hawaiian Mesophotic Algae, instrumental in securing $2.6M of funding for NSF PurSUiT: Discovery and characterization of mesophotic seaweeds in Hawaii: genomic adaptations to low light environments  scaling up our short-read (Illumina) and long-read (Oxford Nanopore) NGS projects to elucidate biodiversity and evolution of non-model organisms in Archaeplastida

Manage all aspects of Sherwood Algal Biodiversity Laboratory including supervising orders, managing priorities across multiple projects, maintaining and developing laboratory protocols, NGS bioinformatics pipelines, and providing mentorship to a diverse group of lab interns and graduate students

Optimized NGS assay development from extraction to library preparation of 250 gorgonians as part of NSF: Novel target-enriched genomic approaches to assess the diversity of Gorgonian Octocorals on Indo-Pacific Mesophotic Coral Reefs

work.company: University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa School of Life Sciences
highlights: Instructed the laboratory sections of BOT 480: Algal Diversity and Evolution and developed teaching resources for botanical techniques e.g. making cross-section slides and herbarium presses, and integrated them into the course curriculum, benefitting 80 students per semester
